title: 105_s448
content: The Act titled "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" addresses the interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. A new section, SEC. 4011, is added to regulate this aspect. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" prohibits out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills or incinerators without local government authorization. Authorization must be granted formally, recorded in writing, and final. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, an affected local government must require the facility owner to provide a brief description of the facility. The facility owner must provide a brief description of the facility, including size, waste capacity, and anticipated quantities of waste to be handled, along with a map indicating location, road system, and hydrogeological features. Buffer zones must also be indicated. The facility owner must provide a map of the facility site showing its location in relation to the local road system, topography, and hydrogeological features. The map should also indicate any buffer zones to be acquired and all facility units. Additionally, a description of the environmental characteristics of the site, including ground water resources and potential alterations, as well as environmental controls such as runon or runoff management and air pollution control, must be included. The curr_chunk describes environmental controls for the facility, including runon or runoff management, air pollution control devices, methane monitoring, landfill covers, and site access controls. It also includes a description of waste residuals management and roadway improvements. The curr_chunk provides details on site access controls, roadway improvements, required permits, personnel requirements, and state law compliance for the facility. The curr_chunk discusses statistics for skill and education levels required before and after the facility's operation, State law requirements for environmental law violations, enforcement proceedings, corrective actions, gifts, and contributions. The curr_chunk discusses State law requirements for gifts, contributions, and compliance with solid waste management plans. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-State waste, affected local governments must notify relevant parties. Affected local governments must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes of the proposed action to handle out-of-State municipal solid waste. They must publish notice in a newspaper at least 30 days before a hearing, provide an opportunity for public comment, and hold at least one public hearing in accordance with State law. The local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes of an authorization granted for handling out-of-State municipal solid waste. This does not apply to landfills or incinerators in operation or under construction within the past year. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must have received documented shipments of out-of-State municipal solid waste or obtained authorization from the local government to accept such waste. The facility must also be in compliance with all applicable Federal and State regulations. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must have received documented shipments of out-of-State municipal solid waste or obtained authorization from the local government to accept such waste. The facility must be in compliance with all applicable Federal and State laws and regulations. The Governor has the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposed of at landfills, in compliance with Clean Air Act requirements and state laws. Landfill or incinerator operators must provide documentation of shipments to the Governor for approval. The Governor may limit the quantity of out-of-state municipal solid waste received for disposal at a landfill to the amount received in the previous year upon request by local government and solid waste planning unit. The Governor may limit the quantity of out-of-state municipal solid waste received at a landfill to the amount received in the previous year upon request by local government and solid waste planning unit. The landfill must be in the State and exempt from certain requirements. Prior to submitting a request, procedural requirements must be met. Prior to submitting a request to limit out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, affected local government and planning unit must provide notice, allow public comment, and take formal action at a public meeting. The Governor can respond to requests by local governments to limit waste quantities received at in-state landfills. The Governor must respond consistently to requests from affected local governments regarding limiting out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal. The Governor's authority is limited if it conflicts with state law or existing disposal contracts. The section addresses the violation or failure to perform provisions in a written contract for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at a landfill. Existing agreements are not affected, and owners must make contracts available for public inspection in the local community. The section requires owners of exempt landfills or incinerators to provide public access to contracts for out-of-State waste disposal, with key details such as waste volume, source, and contract duration visible. States can choose to be exempt from these requirements. The section allows States to be exempt from requirements by notifying the Administrator and referencing the section. Upon notification, the Administrator acknowledges the State's exemption. The Administrator acknowledges State exemptions from requirements by taking appropriate action upon notification. Definitions include 'affected local government' and 'affected local solid waste planning unit'. The term 'affected local solid waste planning unit' refers to a political subdivision with authority over solid waste management planning. A 'host agreement' is a legally binding agreement between a landfill operator and a local government allowing the landfill to receive waste from outside its jurisdiction. 'Municipal solid waste' includes refuse generated by the public or from various sources like paper, wood, and yard waste. The term 'municipal solid waste' refers to solid waste generated by the general public or from residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial sources, consisting of various materials like paper, wood, yard waste, food waste, plastics, leather, rubber, metal, glass, and rock. Exclusions include hazardous waste, waste containing polychlorinated biphenyls, industrial waste, medical waste, and recyclable materials separated from waste destined for disposal. The term 'out-of-State municipal solid waste' in a State refers to waste generated outside of that State. The term 'owner or operator' is defined as the individual responsible for managing waste facilities. The term 'out-of-State municipal solid waste' refers to waste generated outside of a State. The term 'owner or operator' excludes certain entities from being considered as such for landfills or incinerators. The facility only accepts waste generated by the person. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to include a new item in the table of contents related to subtitle D. The Solid Waste Disposal Act is amended to include a new item related to interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste.
